narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Improved reading comprehension in Spanish and new gramatical tenses.
How to speak more fluently, how to learn spanish in a better context
I developed intensive skills in Spanish writing, reading, and speaking. I greatly improved my grammatical abilities as well as written work.
gained a better understanding of grammar, vocabulary, and development of spanish

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength - when we had to talk in class, this forced me to better my Spanish 
Weakness - the constant work due every other day was unnecessary, felt like the asynchronous days were not helpful to my Spanish engagement

Strengths- Supersite assignments are helpful, straightforward testing
Weaknesses- group assignments unorganized, sometimes unclear
Strengths include Profesora Baffi(!!!), the assignments/projects, and the general class structure. Weaknesses include the grading, testing, and the workload.
Lots of discussion and analysis with peers

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Effective - More group projects, enjoyed those, also enjoyed when we had to create our own poems in class, this was cute 
Improvement - such harsh grading on exams, asynchronous days were worth nothing, would have been better to go to all 5 days and actually learn more Spanish

Strengths- adaptation of Spanish courses from 5 synchronous days to 3 synchronous days was incredibly helpful
Weaknesses- much harder to coordinate group projects with people you've never really met

The virtual format was very productive, and breakout rooms were used very appropriately in this course. Virtual presentations were much smoother than they would have been in class, and it was easier to complete assignments in this virtual format. Finally, the mix of synchronous/asynchronous days was extremely valuable and helped make this course feel less overwhelming.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, loved Carolina. She actually did not make me feel bad for my broken Spanish and she encouraged me to do more outside of class. I am doing L4 and am so unhappy that Carolina is not going to be teaching L4. She was able to explain topics very well and always helped us when we needed it. Excellent class with Carolina.

Honestly, yes! I generally hate language learning, and like me you might be taking this course as a requirement. Compared to L2 this course was MUCH better, and even though I wouldn't have taken it without the requirement I would generally recommend it. The workload is steep, especially around testing and at the end of the course, but compared to L2 it was much more reasonable. The grading in this course is pretty fair, and if you do the work you should do well. By far the best part of this class was Profesora Baffi!! If you have to take this course, take it with her!! She is so kind and helpful, and I was never afraid to participate in class because she never forced us to speak if we weren't comfortable, and she wasn't constantly correcting us in demeaning ways as I've had other teachers do before in Spanish. She always spoke in Spanish but in a language level that we could understand, so by the end of the course I had learned A TON of conversational Spanish simply because she made an effort to be immersive but cognizant of our varied learning levels. Overall this course is a lot of work and will not always be fun, but if you take it with Profesora Baffi you will learn lots of Spanish, and the class will generally be neutral if not enjoyable.
Yes! this course greatly improved my understanding of the spanish language

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
